segments.text: Well, what is your name?
Arnulfa Martinez de Medina.
Again, Arnulfa Martinez de Medina.
And where were you born?
In the city of Camargo.
And when did you come here to Texas?
We came in 1913.
Well, tell me, please, these things about the story of your life in the days when you were a girl in Camargo.
When you were a child in Comarga, tell me about your life.
For example, what was your father's name?
My father's name was Romaldo Martínez and my mother's name was Arnulfa Olivares.
He died in 1898.
Yes, he died, my father.
My mother had four children, his children, well married.
And then he got married again in 1900, with another man named Macedonio Carrera.
And he had many children, I still have my brothers.
And what else do I want?
What kind of work did your father have?
My father was a farmer.
He was a capitalist.
That's what they say in my register.
My father was a capitalist.
He lived in his capital.
That's what they say in my register, where he registered me with his mother.
And the second wife of your mother?
The second, yes, she lived with the capital.
Also?
Also.
Capital of what?
Small cattle, they call it cabras.
Oh, cabras.
Cabras.
Did they have a lot of land?
Well, maybe they did, so they had a lot of capital.
It was very extensive, the Mexican land.
In wintertime, the cattlemen would go to the mountains where there was a refuge for the animals, far away.
What kind of house did you have?
A good house.
Yes.
With adobe.
So we used adobe.
Yes.
From Soquete.
The painting to make the houses.
Very good house we had.
With patio?
Yes.
With fruit trees?
Yes.
In the city of Camargo?
In the city of Camargo.
And how many people lived there in the city of Camargo in those days?
Many, many.
And then, for what reason did your family come to Atenas?
Why did we come?
Yes.
Because of the war in the Camargo.
Well, tell me about the war.
Well, I told them.
I told the people that they were very messy and that they did many bad things.
And some of them would do them, maybe.
But my parents, out of fear, dad, my brothers Martínez, who were two men, they were already men, not men, but young boys.
And out of fear that they were going to go to war, they came here with all the cattle that was left.
And we left the house and everything there.
And we came here.
How many people came?
A lot.
Almost all of Camargo came.
Almost all of the town?
Yes.
After that, some came, and others have come now from out there, foreign.
We tell them that they are from outside, foreign.
But some returned to their homes.
We didn't, because Dad didn't leave.
Because here he thought about living, making a living.
I bought some mules and a guayín, I bought a car and a bunch of beasts so that my brothers and sisters could work.
And then they all grew up, my brothers and sisters.
I have a brother who has a very strong store, very big, very good prices, with good possessions.
My brothers and sisters are not very popular.
I still have three brothers and sisters, men and two women.
And we all have good houses to live in.
We are not under huts that serve us.
We are under...
I am a mother, under a good environment.
Why didn't you go back to Camargo after the revolution?
Because they started working here and we made a living here.
I got married here because I was the first and we all got married, we all got married.
What year did you get married?
I got married in 1918.
During the revolution?
No, I think it was over.
There were a lot of foreign troops and they were very bad.
The troops were bad.
My father didn't want to come here.
My father paid the expense.
I didn't know my father.
I can't remember him.
But my father didn't want to come here.
He had a lot of corn.
And they had stored it in a room to use it.
And the bad revolutionaries came, I told them.
Because some came and others didn't.
And they never left the Pacific.
And I didn't want to say that...
Well, the little man, right?
And then they made him run over, or they ran over him, and he said, I don't have any more wine left.
And we thought, the revolution lasted 14 years.
14 years?
14 years it lasted.
Oh, how hard.
That's why we made deposits here, and of housing, and of everything, because that's how we liked it.
We didn't like to go from house to land.
Yes.
Well,
What type of history are you mainly interested in?
Well, I'm interested mainly in... Are you a history major?
No.
After my grandfather died, he was coming to practice.
Uh-huh.
And that grandfather and father, when they came over, they always had the intention to go back.
They had no intention to stay here.
But they never went back, you know, because everybody was born here and grew up here.
They didn't want to go back.
Uh-huh.
Well, she just told me that one reason that they didn't go back is that, you know, they all got married here.
And then she married an American citizen, my father.
And at that time, I don't know if you were familiar with, the law was that if a woman married a foreigner, she would become a citizen of that country.
It used to be that they changed the women's living order.
They changed that.
So she became an American citizen
By marriage.
By just marriage.
And she didn't know until about 20 or 30 years later that she was in a pregnancy.
Actually, on my father's side, they were all
He probably was born here in this state in 1865.
And after the Mexican-American War, they took all this land.
Why don't you leave your chair up close so I can pick you up?
And the people, you know, these people that had lived here even before they were, they were part of Mexico.
And the United States took all this land.
And these people remain here anyway.
My father grew up in this area, even though it was U.S. territory.
But the people that lived here at that time, they still used Mexican currency.
It was just like living in Mexico as far as they were concerned.
So there were lots of connections between, was there a lot of contact back and forth across the river?
There was no such thing as immigration.
Immigration officers.
See, the wealth at that time was to have goats or sheep.
They were pretty well off if you had that capital.
And he crossed with everything.
And that's what she's saying.
He had to get
Oh, when they crossed during the revolution?
That's right.
They brought everything.
Was it easy to get the permission?
¿Estaba fácil para obtener esta permisión de aduanas?
¿De cruzar con todos los animales?
Sí, sí.
Eso era muy, muy gratis todo.
No cobraron.
Ah, no problema.
No.
Sí.
They were very well off, you know, in that type of standard.
My grandfather, my real grandfather, my real one, because she remarried.
Right.
And was very well to do, you know.
He developed quite a bit of capital when he died.
It's funny because at that time, if you owned a horse and had a gun, you were pretty well-to-do.
Just like having a Cadillac nowadays.
You got a car.
When did your family move into this part of Texas?
You say your father was born in 1865?
In Tabasco.
My grandfather was born in 1865.
No, your grandfather was from Rancho El Azucar.
No, but he was an American citizen.
He was an American citizen.
He was born in
Yes, but in 1865, when did the United States take over this land?
Was he born in 1865 or was he born in 1840?
See, he died.
My father was born in 1883.
And his father died when he was a little boy.
So that means he was in his mid-40s.
And my father was...
So that was 1893.
And he was about 45.
Actually, he probably was born closer to that 1845 era.
So it's possible.

See, when the Guadalupe Hidalgo Treaty said that if you lived in this area that they had taken over, you could either remain here and become an American citizen and retain all rights, or you could go back to Mexico.
You had a choice.
So I think that's probably what happened.
They just stayed here.
And by virtue of taking over this land, you became an American citizen.
I was wondering when his forebearers, they must have been among the fairly early colonists of the region.
Very, very early.
His father, my...
Your great-grandfather.
Do you know about your great-grandfather?
We know his name.
What was his name?
He was probably more Indian than Spanish.
What was his name?
Benigno.
No, Benigno was the father of Apollonio.
My great-grandfather was named Apollonio Medina.
Apollonio Medina.
Apollonio.
Do you remember his name?
And my grandfather was Benigno, which I had a brother.
What makes you think he was more Indian than Spanish?
Because my father used to say that he remembered him as just like an Indian, the way that he was, barefooted and dressed in long hair.
So he would say he was just like an Indian.
And then my grandfather became very well-to-do because they were cattlemen.
This is on your father's side.
My father's side.
They were raising cattle.
Now, on your mother's side, they were raising goats.
Right.
Right.
And they were all, from my grandfather and all his brother-in-laws, they were all cattlemen.
They used to, my grandfather used to, when they'd have these drives to Kansas, they'd bring beef on them.
He used to be a trail driver.
That was his job.
Tell me something.
Before that, before the Kansas drives, did they ever drive the cattle south to Mexico?
Back to the markets?
Well, I'll bet you anything they did, because I've got some documentation on cattle drives as far south as San Luis Potosi going back to the 18th century.
This is what's interesting is, you know, I wonder, where did my grandfather learn this trade?
He learned this trade because they were driving, from 1750 on, they were driving cattle
Five and six hundred miles south of the Perilla Market in central Mexico.
I've just found this out, and I'm really excited about it.
All the brothers-in-law of my father were experts.
They were experts as far as that business was concerned.
So they had to learn it, like you say.
It's obvious that that's how it is.
They already knew how to do it.
They didn't learn it here.
And the Anglos didn't invent it.
No.
It was already going on, and so really what seems to have happened is the direction of the drives changed.
And then eventually they took over.
It's just like on that Guadalupe Treaty, we seem to have forgotten it.
I live in Virginia.
There's not very many Spanish-speaking people down there.
Not very many.
Very few.
According to the treaties, you know, these people that remain here, it said that they could retain, if they had land, if they had land, they could retain title to their land.
They could retain their own language and their own customs and their own religion.
This was, you know, guaranteed.
And, of course, see, now we run into the problem that, like, when I went to school here, it was against regulations to speak Spanish.
Against regulations?
In the school grounds.
And it's understandable why.
I can understand why.
But it's still against what was first understood.
Well, tell me, have they brought in the bilingual education program here where you should be learning both languages from first grade on?
Here in Texas, I'm not very familiar, but I just read a book recently.
The Constitution of New Mexico was set up
where the school systems were to be set up bilingual and to be taught by people that could speak both languages, which of course wasn't done.
That's why, you know who Reyes Tijerina is?
He's been raised in hell, but then he's in jail.
But, of course, he wants his land back.
He says it's theirs.
But he ain't gonna get it back.
He says that...
The Jews got their land back in Palestine.
This is my brother-in-law.
I'm Mary Lee Nolan from College Station.
How's everything up there?
Fine, fine.
You can say that here.
Over there?
Yes, it's hot up there, but it's just as hot here.
It's hotter here because of the dust.
He says that the Jews got back their land.
They felt that they'd been there for centuries and centuries, and there's no law to take it away from them.
And we supported him.
Eric said, we should get the land back.
And he said, well, why can't we get ours?
He probably, I'd love to see his flames.
He says he's had them.
I've never seen them.
He may have them because there was a lot of slicky business.
Yeah, with the Santa Fe ring and all that.
He's mainly in New Mexico.
He's very radical.
He's an extremist, I think.
But sometimes, you know, that's what he thinks.
If you have people that are too peaceful, you ain't going to get anything done.
That's what he thought.

I've got a friend here, and I haven't seen him in years, because I haven't lived here in 10 years, that his grandparents, all his grandparents, I don't remember which, they came from Spain originally.
They had a grant from the king of Spain, giving them, I've forgotten how many, thousands of acres, 25, 30,000, 50,000.
So when this happened, So when it changed, the land changed, the U.S. government was good enough about it that they retained title to their land.
They didn't lose it.
Like in California, all these people lost it.
They had the Russian, they didn't have it in Texas.
So they still have about 25,000 acres right now.
They still retain their title.
But it'd be interesting, I don't know how much he knows to see how and where his grandparents were, his great-grandparents when this changes.
A lot of the people I know in Zapata and Webb counties, most of the titles were respected.
Now, I don't know how it was down here and on down toward Brownsville, but I've looked at a lot of the court records in Webb and Zapata.
Now, a lot of people, one thing that happened to the lands is that the titles would come into controversy and lawyers would clear it up and get a good copy.
for clearing the tides, but the tides were ultimately respected in that area.
And where were they from?
Where did they come from?
From Camargo.
They were from Camargo too?
Yes.
And they came here during the revolution?
Yes.
So they lived, it was the same thing, they just crossed the river.
And why did they have their lands here?
Because they lived in Camargo.
Actually it was all Mexico.
They had an agreement, the lands from here,
They used to bring their cows across the river, depending on where it was better grazed.
So they actually, on your father's side, they lived in Camargo part of the time and raised their cattle.
Let me see.
Papá nunca vivió en Camargo, ¿no?
¿Tu papá?
Ellos siempre vivieron acá en La Joya.
Sí, tu papá no vivió nunca aquí.
Ni nosotros hasta que no nos venimos.
See, actually, my father always was on this side of the river.
But on your mother's side, they would bring their cattle back and forth across the river.
Do you have land here on this side as well?
Yes, also.
A lot of land?
A lot, a lot of things.
How many hectares?
How many acres?
No, I can't tell you.
It's just that there were a lot.
A lot?
I can't tell you because my people...
They didn't work with them.
My family wasn't working with them.
They worked on their own.
Only on their own.
Your father?
Your father was Martínez, right?
Yes, that's why I called him Martínez.
And he wasn't from Camargo originally.
No.
Your father was.
Your father was?
The one who was was my grandfather, Miguel Martínez.
He was from China.
From China.
My grandfather.
Your grandfather.
Let's see.
No, my grandfather was Miguel.
He was my grandfather.

mis abuelos it goes so far back it's just like uh first cousin she's from mexico and they used to own a lot of land they used to have you know acres and acres and when all this changed and all this you know some people took over anyway she was
Just recently, she was trying to get the land back, but we didn't have any records.
She went through all the records in Mexico.
This is land in Mexico she was trying to get back.
Yeah, well, the revolution kind of took care of a lot of that.
And they just couldn't get the land back.
I'd like to know more about how the decision was made to actually move over here to this side of the border.
¿Quién decidió?
¿Papá no nos decidió venirse para acá?
Pues el temor nos hizo venirnos.
¿Pero quién hizo la decisión?
Pues papá y mamá.
Pues papá y mamá.
En la noche llegaron los primeros tropas.
And they were destroying, shooting, and scaring people in the streets.
And they took the horses too, right?
Yes, the horses, they took everything.
Animals, I don't tell you, corn, everything that was destroyed, they threw everything at the animals, just like that.
And all the things from your house too?
They would take everything.
No, no, the houses.
They wouldn't take the houses?
Well, yes, but later, yes.
Well, yes, later, yes.
That's why they left.
Because the other day we woke up here.
It was a complete evacuation because my grandmother's brothers, they all lived here.
They were olivares.
And this was in 1913.
That was in 1913?
1913, in May.
In May of 1913?
Yes, in May of 1913.
And who are the bad troops from?
From Carranza?
From all of them.
Some came and others went with other names and other names like that.
Many, many, and it's not important from whom.
And in Camargo, are there sides in the revolution?
How do you say it?
How would you say, were they on either side?
Did they have any political...
I know what you're trying to say.
I think I know the answer, but I don't know.
It's something that's been a question in my mind always.
Because I used to tell my grandfather, if I were a baby, I wouldn't have left.
I would have fought there.
I would have made my stand.
Who would you have fought for?
For myself, for my land.
For your own land, right there.
But you would have been a non-combatant.
Right, I would have lost.
In defense of, you wouldn't have been, you'd have lost.
But I wouldn't have died, but I wouldn't have died.
There were many names of those who came.
And you, I mean, the whole revolution is your strength.
And you didn't have any interest in who won?
No.
See, this is what I never could understand, but I can't.
I've got an idea that you've got a group of people that are isolated.
They're isolated from politics.
They're very poor, very poor people.
The only thing they had...
The president.
The president.
Yes, the president of the nation.
Francisco Madero.
Francisco Madero.
His people.
No, in Mexico.
In Mexico.
The president of Mexico and the city of Mexico.
Yes, but the people of your people, do they like Madero?
No, they didn't take decisions.
No, they didn't have political things.
They didn't have meetings or elections.
No, there are no elections?
No.
Was he a mayor of Camargo?
Well, not in Camargo, he was from Mexico.
When you lived there?
In Camargo, yes.
How did he become mayor?
I don't know.
Didn't they vote?
Yes, before the war.
Before the war, they did vote.
They all voted.
Yes, before the war.
Before the war.
But when there was war, there was no peace, there was no tranquility, there was nothing.
That's why we didn't go.
Because there was no government.
There was no government.
And there were some people who took care of us.
In the Camargo presidency,
But my, this other, like I say, my grandfather, but he's not really my grandfather, that's the only person that I knew, because her father died when she was young, so I was at home.
He used to say that...
He used to say that...
He had his, you know, you had your horse there and the soldiers would come and they would take him.
So, he was the only one from his family.
Yes.
Pancho Villa?
Ah, yes, yes.
But is it after your family came here?
No, we were here.
We only had the newspapers.
They ask me about the newspapers.
60 years ago.
How did they protect you here?
Who protected you on this side of the river?
You had American soldiers.
So who protected you?
No, by law.
Which law?
The Cote.
If the soldiers could get to Camargo, why didn't they get here?
They came here once, but with permission.
on the 21st of March, because they were afraid, because they were afraid that they would be thrown on top of them.
And then, how do you call the one in charge of the court?
The judge?
No, no, the one in charge of the court is Álvarez.
What does he do?
He's the head of the whole town.
He was a warlord, and he ordered the families not to go out.
And that they were allowed to go in because they were being thrown on us and they were killing us.
And that's how they did it.
They came in with a lot of peace, with things of gender, loaded and giving to the people.
But we didn't go out.
And another thing was that
These people didn't have any weapons, I say.
No, they didn't have any weapons.
No, they didn't have any weapons, I say.
No, they didn't have any weapons, I say.
No, they didn't have any weapons, I say.
No, they didn't have any weapons, I say.
No, they didn't have any weapons, I say.
And that's how all the noble, good people got together, because they were afraid.
Yes.
Fear, danger, danger.
And the women, especially, or the men too?
The men too.
They were all afraid.
My father had the bonfire on for the cattle, and he left it on.
He let it go.
He got angry.
Because there were a lot of people without law.
They didn't have law.
Because all the old people were prisoners.
There in Camargo they took a boy and we never saw him again.
And they killed him there in Camargo.
Those things.
Are there people who live in Camargo now?
Yes, a lot of people.
It's peaceful, you have your law.
Did those people return to Camargo?
No.
How did they get up again?
Some people returned and others...
They came from other places.
Now they have a lot of people.
Not yet.
Now there is a lot of people and a lot of order and everything.
Cases happen wherever they want, but the people are with their order, with their law.
Yes.
Well, in which country do you think life is better, here or in Mexico now?
Well, here.
Here?
Why?
Because here there is a lot of work.
It's a difficult question.
This, of course, is a richer country.
We can't deny that.
It's more advanced politically.
Yes, women too.
You'd rather live in Mexico.
Why?
Because I like the way of life.
It's very nice out there in Monterrey, in Mexico, Guadalajara.
It's more relaxed.
No, it's very nice.
My daughters are going to walk in the shadows.
Because I have three daughters who are teachers.
You?
Married women.
This is one of them.
And I have another one who lives in Macaulay.
Here I have two.
How many children do you have?
I had 11, thank you.
All of them were born.
11 children.
And 3 are teachers.
I have Marcos, Arturo, Ella, Marta.
Marta is 4.
4 teachers.
And the others, what kind of work?
I'm a Carly Boomerang technician.
I'm in the Air Force.
The other brothers, what happened to them, one was killed in World War II at 22 years old.
The other one was killed in an accident when he was 27.
He was the man.
And my oldest brother.
My oldest brother didn't go to college.
He was also inducted in World War II.
He lost his left arm.
Y mis hijos vivimos bien cuando menos.
No somos ricos, pero vivimos bien.
I went for three years and I quit.
You went to college for three years.
Pues las otras también fueron al colegio, pero no alcanzaron.
And the other one, my other sister did go for two or three years and she got married.
Now, what is your name?
Alfredo.
Alfredo.
And what are you?
You're one of the younger.
I'm the youngest.
You're the youngest.
You're the baby of the family.
Él es de la barrica.
That one?
Yes.
Well, and your husband?
What kind of work did he have?
Well, he was a manual laborer.
But he had land, right?
We had cows and we had goats.
Yes, and land of your own?
Of my own.
And the children, all my children went to school, well, all of them.
The one who didn't take out his griffin was because he didn't want to.
But we all live well, we never live badly.
Thank God, I say, thank God.
She just told you that she did it.
Thank God.
I am very...
I believe a lot in God.
I believe a lot in God.
He has led me through mysterious paths that I did not think about.
I have a master's son.
I did not think about it.
But one of them began to think.
And we continued.
I have one who is a teacher, who is in McAllen.
They were putting her to study so that she could calm down for a while.
To write, and there was a little girl.
And she asked me for a pencil sharpener and I gave it to her.
Because it was her, so that she was happy.
And my father came, who raised me, my stepfather.
And he said, and my daughter, what are you going to do?
I, dad, no, no.
Maita, teacher.
I said, Maita.
For what reason did your husband and I have this, how do you say, this...
Because he didn't know how to read.
And I don't know how to read.
Yes.
How old were you?
How old were you when you went to school?
Well, I think I didn't complete it.
I should learn to read and write.
In Camargo.
Read and write, because in the Methodist Church we read and write.
And I didn't like it when I entered the religion, I didn't like to do it unless I knew how to read.
When did you learn to write?
In school.
At what age?
16 or 17 years old.
Ah, not in Camargo.
In Camargo, yes.
Oh, 16 years.
And it ended at 18?
Yes, at 18.
But I kept writing and reading books.
I liked reading books.
I liked reading.
I liked reading.
And I like it.
Yes?
Yes.
And for this reason, these things were important to you all your life.
And your husband also went to school?
No, he didn't.
He didn't?
Precisely, this is what took us to school, the children, what he didn't know.
He said, when we got married, we're not going to leave our children without knowing.
We have to look for them.
They go to school.
They liked school.
But because in those years, people were very decisive.
Yes.
They didn't like school.
Well, my brothers didn't want, they didn't accept that my daughter went to school.
Oh, yes.
Yes, they did.
This is difficult to understand.
No.
This is difficult to understand, and it still is in Mexico.
In Mexico, higher learning is strictly cultural.
You go to school, it's like a luxury.
Culture is a luxury.
In this country, as far as I'm concerned, you can make a living without having to go to school, as long as you know the basics.
The hard earning is just for culture.
In this country, of course, it's the worst.
You have to have this education to get a job.
But my husband told his children that he had lost a lot of good jobs because he didn't know how to read or write or count.
And that led him to have an idea to educate his children.
But we didn't think we were going to have teachers.
No, I didn't think about it in those years.
Education wasn't worth anything.
No?
No.
There was no education, so it wasn't worth anything.
I was in a ranch and I took out a bus full of votes so that I could take my children to school and others.
The whole ranch fell into the school.
But I looked for votes.
Yes?
Yes.
So that they would give me the bus to take them abroad.
That's what I did.
The interest.
I knew that my children knew about it.
He was very loving, and he was just like me.
We thought the same, I think.
He was my son, he was old and his father died when he got married.
He was never talking, fighting, saying bad words.
He was the one who said it.
We talked at the table and everything we were going to do, very peaceful.
They were all Catholics.
In Mexico, everybody's a Catholic.
She thought she had changed.
Oh.
And he had children and even met a grandson.
And his wife and I were there when Kirby died, one of the veterans.
And we came home at midnight, we took care of everything, very happy.
Only with God and Christ.
When they were there, they also had another turning point.
When we had World War II, when World War II began, the boys were old enough to go to war.
